results.title: Needing At-Home Workers, Call Centers Turn to People With Disabilities
results.abstract: Companies caught short by the pandemic are hiring from a pool that was already prepared to handle a surge in phone traffic away from offices.

multimedia.caption: Only a handful of employees continue working from their cubicles during the coronavirus pandemic at the ASK Telemarketing call center. Most of the rest are working from home.
multimedia.copyright: Bob Miller for The New York Times

results.title: Governments Release Prisoners to Halt Coronavirus: Live World Coverage
results.abstract: Boris Johnson is back at Downing Street and will return to work Monday after recovering. Children in Spain play outside for the first time in weeks. Wuhan says it has no more hospitalized Covid-19 patients.

multimedia.caption: An injured inmate with military police officers during a prison rebellion this month in Rio de Janeiro.
An injured inmate with military police officers during a prison rebellion this month in Rio de Janeiro.
An injured inmate with military police officers during a prison rebellion this month in Rio de Janeiro.
An injured inmate with military police officers during a prison rebellion this month in Rio de Janeiro.

results.title: Trump Suggests Daily Briefings No Longer Worth His Time as White House Considers Replacing Health Secretary
results.abstract: States move to reopen as the U.S. nears a sobering 50,000 deaths from the virus. U.S. scientists join the World Health Organization in calling for better antibody tests.

multimedia.caption: White House officials are discussing replacing Alex M. Azar II, the health and human services secretary, center, as the administration faces criticism for its coronavirus response.
White House officials are discussing replacing Alex M. Azar II, the health and human services secretary, center, as the administration faces criticism for its coronavirus response.

results.title: March, April, May: City’s Mood Darkens as Crisis Feels Endless
results.abstract: With no clues about when the pandemic might subside, short-term discomfort is becoming long-term despair: “I feel like I have accepted this, and given up.”

multimedia.caption: What constitutes street life these days outside the Melrose Houses in the Bronx.
What constitutes street life these days outside the Melrose Houses in the Bronx.

results.title: Americans Stranded Abroad Weigh Options; Spain Announces Easing of Restrictions
results.abstract: Belarus, led by a virus-denying autocrat, has imposed no lockdowns. Brazil’s leader, who has played down the virus, faces an uncertain future.

multimedia.caption: Newark Liberty International Airport last week. The State Department is warning that commercial flights to the United States from overseas may end in the coming days and urging Americans abroad to grab any opportunity to board them.

results.title: California Lifts Ban on Plastic Bags Amid Virus Concerns
results.abstract: For the next 60 days, supermarkets in the state can hand out single-use bags without charging. Some are skeptical that suspending the ban will protect anyone’s health.

multimedia.caption: Single-use plastic bags have been banned in California since 2016.
Single-use plastic bags have been banned in California since 2016.

results.title: ‘Playing Russian Roulette’: Nursing Homes Told to Take the Infected
results.abstract: California, New Jersey and New York have made nursing homes accept Covid-19 patients from hospitals. Residents and workers fear the policy is risking lives.
results.byline: By Kim Barker and Amy Julia Harris

multimedia.caption: Nursing homes have been particularly vulnerable to the pandemic. The Life Care Center of Kirkland, in Washington State, was linked to dozens of coronavirus deaths.
multimedia.copyright: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times

results.title: I Was Ready to Help Fight the Pandemic. Then I Got Sick Myself.
results.abstract: As a surgeon, I anticipated seeing Covid-19 through the eyes of a medical professional. But being a patient was a different matter.
results.byline: By David Hirsch and C. J. Chivers

results.title: What’s a Pulse Oximeter, and Do I Really Need One at Home?
results.abstract: A tiny fingertip device can give you valuable information about your health during a bout of Covid-19 or any respiratory illness.

results.title: Could the Power of the Sun Slow the Coronavirus?
results.abstract: A study suggests that ultraviolet rays could slow the virus, though not enough to wipe it out, and not as a treatment.

multimedia.caption: A sunbathing New Yorker on Sunday.

results.title: Trump’s Remarks Prompt Warnings on Disinfectants
results.abstract: Several states take tentative steps to reopen businesses. The Navy recommended reinstating the captain of an aircraft carrier who had sought help as the virus spread on his ship.

results.title: How to Create Screen-Life Balance When Life Has Shifted to Screens
results.abstract: Being thoughtful about our use of screens can help us emerge from this crisis empowered and in control, and with more self-awareness.

results.title: Weekly Health Quiz: We're All Learning More About Coronavirus
results.abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news

results.title: Trump Muses About Light as Remedy, but Also Disinfectant, Which Is Dangerous
results.abstract: At a briefing, the president promoted unproven treatments and asked Dr. Deborah Birx if she had heard of the success of sunlight as a tool against viruses.
results.byline: By William J. Broad and Dan Levin

multimedia.caption: President Trump at a coronavirus briefing on Thursday. “Supposing we hit the body with a tremendous — whether it’s ultraviolet or just very powerful light,” he said.

results.title: C.D.C. Stresses Need for Coronavirus Testing at Homeless Shelters
results.abstract: A study of four cities suggested that those living in close quarters in shelters can spread the virus at high rates even when asymptomatic.

results.title: When Mental Distress Comes Home
results.abstract: The pandemic has closed many mental-health residential centers, sending residents home to families ill-equipped for the challenges.

results.title: Nearly All Patients Hospitalized With Covid-19 Had Chronic Health Issues, Study Finds
results.abstract: Only 6 percent of patients at one New York area health system had no chronic conditions. Hypertension, obesity and diabetes were common.
org_facet: Journal of the American Medical Assn

results.title: 1 in 5 New Yorkers May Have Had Covid-19, Antibody Tests Suggest
results.abstract: Accurate antibody testing is a critical tool to determine if the pandemic has slowed enough to begin restarting the economy.
results.byline: By J. David Goodman and Michael Rothfeld

results.title: Be a Friend to the Elderly, Get Paid
results.abstract: Combating loneliness is vital work. Services that offer ‘grandkids on demand’ are doing just that.

results.title: Hospitals Play ‘Songs of Hope’ as Virus Patients Go Home
results.abstract: Anthems like “Don’t Stop Believin’,” the “Rocky” theme and “Every Breath You Take” have been adopted by hospitals to celebrate each victory in the battle against coronavirus.

multimedia.caption: Karla Duarte, holding a colorful poster signed by the nursing staff, was discharged on Sunday to the tune of “Ain’t No Mountain High Enough.”

results.title: What to Say (and Not Say) to Workers on the Front Lines
results.abstract: Send messages of support, without the expectation of a reply.

results.title: Goggles, Masks, Ponchos: Air Travel in the Thick of a Pandemic
results.abstract: Some people who have had to board commercial flights in recent weeks have taken elaborate precautions to protect themselves from the coronavirus.
results.byline: By Vivian Lin and Thomas Fuller

results.title: Death Toll Climbs in California; House Passes Aid Package
results.abstract: President Trump said he would sign the $484 billion package, which replenishes a depleted small-business loan program. Another 4.4 million people filed for unemployment.

results.title: Vaccine Rates Drop Dangerously as Parents Avoid Doctor’s Visits
results.abstract: Afraid of Covid-19, parents are postponing well-child checkups, including shots, putting millions of children at risk of exposure to preventable deadly diseases.

multimedia.caption: Carson Sheffield, 18 months old, was attended to by Dr. Mona Doss of Boston Medical Center, as Priscilla Stout, left, prepared a vaccine for him. The pediatric ambulatory department began sending mobile vaccination units into city neighborhoods last week.
multimedia.copyright: David Degner for The New York Times
